scenes.title: The Broken Window
scenes.text: The fog is thick. It tastes like metal and damp plaster. I pull myself through the broken window of the pediatric ward. Glass crunches under my boots. The air inside is cold and still, heavy with the smell of antiseptic and something else. Something sweet and rotten, like old meat. Distant, thin screaming slices through the silence, then stops. Moonlight paints long, skeletal fingers across the peeling floor. My sister, Lily, was here. I have to know why she never came home.

scenes.title: The Long Hall
scenes.text: I step into the hallway. The floor is a checkerboard of grimy tiles. Wheelchairs lie on their sides like dead beetles. Along the walls, faded murals of smiling cartoon animals are defaced with dark, brownish stains. From down the hall, I hear a soft, rhythmic clicking. Tick... tock... tick... It's the sound of a toy, but wrong. It sounds wet.

choices.text: Try the door marked 'Dr. Albright - Head Surgeon'.

scenes.title: The Playroom
scenes.text: The playroom is full of them. Dolls with button eyes and stitched-on smiles made of red surgical thread. A teddy bear with hypodermic needles for claws sits in a tiny chair. They are all posed, watching the door. As I enter, their heads turn in perfect, silent unison. Their button eyes fix on me. The air grows tight. A music box on a shelf begins to play a warped, stuttering lullaby.

scenes.title: The Surgeon Bear
scenes.text: I move towards the clicking. It leads me to a small operating theater. In the center, under a surgical lamp, is a huge teddy bear. It's at least seven feet tall, stuffed with something that isn't cotton. Its fur is matted with old blood. In one paw, it holds a bone saw. In the other, a spool of red thread. It's 'operating' on a jack-in-the-box, trying to stitch its painted smile wider. It turns its glassy eyes to me. The clicking stops. 'A new patient,' a voice rumbles, a sound like gravel and static coming from its stitched mouth.

scenes.title: The Doctor's Office
scenes.text: The office is a mess. Papers are scattered everywhere. A thick layer of dust covers everything except a large leather-bound journal on the desk. A strange diagram is on the wall, a twisted medical chart showing a child's body connected by wires and tubes to a collection of toys. It looks like a circuit diagram for a soul. I feel a deep, penetrating cold, as if the room itself is remembering something awful.

scenes.title: A Swarm of Smiles
scenes.text: The moment my boot connects, a shriek fills the room. It doesn't come from one doll, but from all of them. They surge forward. A tide of porcelain and plush. The teddy bear with needle-claws leaps onto my back, plunging its syringes deep into my shoulders. I feel a cold, thick fluid pumping into me. The other dolls swarm my legs, their tiny hands surprisingly strong. They drag me down. Their stitched mouths are so close to my face. 'We just want to fix you,' they whisper in a chorus of children's voices. 'We just want to make you smile.'

scenes.title: The Unflinching Patient
scenes.text: The tray of scalpels and clamps clatters against the bear's chest. It doesn't even flinch. It just tilts its head, a slow, curious gesture. 'Disruptive,' the static voice rumbles. 'The procedure will be... corrective.' It moves faster than anything that big should. The bone saw whirs to life, a hungry, metallic scream. It pins me against the wall. I see my own terrified face reflected in its dead glass eyes. The saw comes down. It doesn't just cut. It reshapes.

scenes.title: Emotional Surgery
scenes.text: I open the journal. Albright's handwriting is a frantic scrawl. He wasn't healing children. He called it 'emotional surgery.' He believed sorrow was a cancer that could be cut out. He designed the toys to absorb the children's pain, to become living reservoirs of trauma. But the toys became... hungry. The last entry reads: 'They have perfected the Suture-Smile. They took Lily for the final procedure. They say she is the key. They keep her in the Recovery Ward. They are waiting for her to... activate.'

scenes.title: A Heavy Tool
scenes.text: I ignore the book. It feels wrong to read it. I search the office instead. In a filing cabinet, under a pile of rotted paperwork, I find a heavy iron crowbar. It feels solid in my hands, a piece of the real world in this nightmare. As my fingers wrap around it, I hear a soft giggle from the hallway. It sounds like Lily. It's coming from the end of the hall, from a door marked 'Recovery Ward'.

scenes.title: The Recovery Ward
scenes.text: The Recovery Ward is a long room lined with dozens of small, metal-frame beds. On each pillow sits a doll, identical except for the names embroidered on their little outfits. The air hums with a low, electrical thrum. In the center of the room is a large, old-fashioned music box made of dark, polished wood, humming with a sickly green light. Wires run from it, burrowing under the floor towards each bed. At the very back of the ward, in a bed marked 'LILY', sits a doll that looks just like her. Her smile is stitched with shining silver thread.

scenes.title: Her Silver Smile
scenes.text: I walk to the back of the ward. The doll's button eyes follow me. As I get closer, I see it's clutching a small, worn teddy bearâ€”her favorite, Barnaby. This thing... it's not just a doll. It's a vessel. It contains all her fear, all her pain. Her voice, a tiny, broken whisper, echoes in my head. 'It hurts... Make it stop hurting.' The silver thread in its smile seems to glow brighter.

scenes.title: Shattered Lullaby
scenes.text: I can't face the doll. Not yet. If I found the crowbar, I grip it tight. If not, I use a metal bedpan. I swing at the music box. The wood splinters. The green light sputters and dies with a sound like a final, drawn-out breath. A collective, agonized shriek erupts from every doll in the room. They go limp, falling over on the beds. The silver thread on Lily's doll unravels, and it slumps forward, now just a toy. The oppressive weight in the air is gone. A service door at the back of the ward, previously locked, clicks open.

scenes.title: Letting Go
scenes.text: I touch the doll's porcelain hand. It's ice cold. 'I'm so sorry I wasn't here,' I whisper. A single tear, thick and black like oil, rolls from one of its button eyes. The silver thread of its smile dissolves into dust. For a moment, a faint, shimmering image of Lily stands before me. She is smiling, a real smile. She points to a fire escape behind her bed, a door I never saw before. Then she fades. The room is just a room now. The dolls are just dolls. I am alone, but the screaming has finally stopped.

scenes.title: A Shared Smile
scenes.text: I grab the doll, my anger boiling over. 'Give her back!' I scream. The doll's head snaps up. Its button eyes glow with a fierce red light. The voice in my head is no longer a whisper. It is a roar. 'WE ARE ONE. WE ARE FIXED. YOU ARE BROKEN.' A searing pain shoots up my arm from the doll. I feel something tearing inside my own head, something being stitched together. I look down at my reflection in a polished bedpan. A smile is carving itself into my own face, pulled tight by invisible, bloody threads. I am part of the collection now. I will help them fix the others.
